title: AB 1685
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. A person violating provisions of Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code may be subject to a civil penalty of up to $37,500 per action. Violations related to portable fuel containers or small off-road engines may incur a penalty of up to $500 per unit. Manufacturers or distributors who violate these provisions may also face penalties. Violations related to portable fuel containers or small off-road engines may result in a civil penalty of up to $500 per unit. Manufacturers or distributors who violate emission control laws may be required to pay the penalty and ensure compliance with regulations to continue selling their products in the state. The state board adjusts maximum penalties for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Penalties collected are deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43151 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. Section 43151 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to require certification for new motor vehicles or engines in California. Penalties collected under this section go to the Air Pollution Control Fund. The article does not apply to vehicles acquired for replacing a damaged or stolen vehicle, vehicles transferred by inheritance or court decree, or vehicles sold after a specific legislative amendment. The article does not apply to vehicles acquired for replacing a damaged or stolen vehicle, vehicles transferred by inheritance or court decree, or vehicles sold after a specific legislative amendment. This exemption does not cover vehicles that were registered in the state before the effective date of the amendments. This chapter does not apply to motor vehicles with a federal Clean Air Act certificate of conformity originally registered in another state by a resident who moves to this state and provides proof of previous registration. This provision takes effect 180 days after regulations are adopted for certifying new direct import vehicles. Section 43154 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to allow for a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for violations of emission control laws. Manufacturers or distributors may also be required to pay the penalty and ensure compliance with the laws to continue selling motor vehicles in the state. The state board may impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 on dealers who violate emission control laws, with adjustments for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index. This penalty is separate from the one imposed on manufacturers or distributors under Section 43154 of the Health and Safety Code. Any action to recover a penalty under this section shall be brought in the name of the people of the State of California in the superior court of the county where the violation occurred, by the Attorney General on behalf of the state board, or by the district attorney, county attorney, or city attorney. Penalties adjudged by the court shall be deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund or with the treasurer of the county or city. Section 43211 of the Health and Safety Code states that a new motor vehicle sold in California must meet emission standards set by the state board. Manufacturers selling vehicles that do not meet these standards may face a civil penalty of up to $37,500 per violation. (a) A new motor vehicle in California must meet state emission standards, with a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for non-compliance. For failing to meet zero-emission vehicle credit requirements, the penalty is capped at $5,000 per credit. The civil penalty for failure to meet zero-emission vehicle credit requirements in California is capped at $5,000 per credit. The state board will adjust the maximum penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index. The state board will adjust the maximum penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Any penalty recovered will be deposited into the General Fund. Section 43212 of the Health and Safety Code is amended. Section 43212 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for each vehicle that does not comply with emission standards or test procedures. Non-compliant manufacturers or distributors may be required to pay penalties and make vehicles compliant before further sales in the state. The state board will adjust the maximum penalty for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Any penalty collected will go into the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43214 is added to the Health and Safety Code. The state board may order a manufacturer to bring its vehicles into compliance with certified emissions configuration, with compliance required for continued sale in the state. Penalties collected will be deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund.
